context: Cytotoxicity Viability of fibroblasts in dermal equivalents was assessed using the MTT assay. Exposure to m-xylene resulted in a time- and dose-dependent decrease in fibroblast viability after 1- or 4-h (Fig. 1 ). Using non-linear regression analysis of dermal equivalent viability plotted against the calculated fibroblast concentration, the EC50 were calculated to be 1481.1±88.2 and 930.4±32.5 μg m-xylene/g cells at 1 and 4 h, respectively (Table 1 ). The observed EC50 at 1 h was ≈60% higher than the EC50 at 4 h.Endogenous catalase and thiol levels Endogenous catalase activity in the living dermal equivalents exposed to m-xylene decreased in a temporal and dose-dependent manner (Fig. 2 ). At 1 and 4 h, catalase activity decreased significantly (P<0.05) with increasing chemical concentration. The mean (±S.E.M.) observed changes in absorbance values at 240 nm per minute (normalized to protein), reflecting catalase activity in the sham-exposed controls, were 0.037±0.001 and 0.042±0.002

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,3-xylene exposure is linked to a decrease in catalase activity in fibroblasts within dermal equivalents. The study shows that as the concentration of m-xylene increases, catalase activity declines in a time- and dose-dependent manner, indicating a potential toxic effect of 1,3-xylene on cellular antioxidant defenses. This suggests that 1,3-xylene may impair the ability of fibroblasts to manage oxidative stress, as evidenced by the significant reduction in catalase activity observed at both 1 and 4 hours post-exposure.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 4 reflects a significant connection between 1,3-xylene and catalase activity, supported by quantitative data showing a clear dose-dependent decrease in catalase activity due to m-xylene exposure. This indicates a relevant interaction in the context of cellular toxicity and oxidative stress.
